content: Contract law governs legally binding agreements between two or more parties. It ensures that promises made are enforceable by law, provided that the contract is valid.
There are several essential elements for a valid contract: offer, acceptance, consideration, intention to create legal relations, capacity, and legality of object.
An offer is a definite promise to be bound provided certain terms are accepted. It must be clear, certain, and communicated to the offeree.

title: Carlill v Carbolic Smoke Ball Co. (1893) 1 QB 256
content:
Facts: The company promised £100 to anyone who used their product and still contracted influenza. Mrs. Carlill did and sued for the money.
Judgment: The court held it was a valid unilateral offer accepted by performance.
Acceptance is the final and unqualified expression of assent to the terms of an offer. It must be communicated and mirror the terms of the offer.

title: Entores Ltd v Miles Far East Corporation (1955) 2 QB 327
content:
Facts: Communication of acceptance via telex between companies in London and Amsterdam.
Judgment: Acceptance must be effectively communicated to create a contract.
Consideration is something of value given by both parties to a contract that induces them to enter into the agreement.

title: Currie v Misa (1875) LR 10 Ex 153
content: Consideration is a right, interest, profit, benefit, or forbearance, detriment, loss, or responsibility given or suffered.
The parties must intend that the agreement creates obligations enforceable by law. Social/domestic agreements usually lack such intention.

title: Balfour v Balfour (1919) 2 KB 571
content:
Facts: A husband promised to send money to his wife while abroad.
Judgment: No legal intention in domestic arrangements; no enforceable contract.
